{{improve references|date=August 2017}} An '''own goal''' is an event in competitive goal-scoring sports (such as [[association football]] or [[hockey]]) where a player scores on their own side of the playing area rather than the one defended by the opponent. Own goals sometimes result from the opponent's defensive strength, as when the player is stopped in the scoring area,{{Clarification needed|reason=Whose scoring area, his own or the opponent's? What does this have to do with the opponent's defensive strength?|date=December 2017}} but can also happen by accident. Since own goals are often added to the opponent's score, they are often an embarrassing blunder for the scoring player, but in certain sports are occasionally done for strategic reasons.
In some parts of the world, the term has become a [[metaphor]] for ''any'' action that backfires on the person/group undertaking it, sometimes even carrying a sense of "[[poetic justice]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/own+goal |title=thefreedictionary.com |publisher=thefreedictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref>
A player trying to [[Match fixing|throw a game]] might deliberately attempt an own goal.<ref>http://www.eurosport.com/football/teams-kicked-out-of-league-after-farcical-own-goal-match_sto4714595/story.shtml</ref> Such players run the risk of being sanctioned or banned from further play.
==Association football== In [[association football]], an own goal occurs when a player causes the ball to go into his or her own team's [[Goal (sport)|goal]], resulting in a [[Scoring in association football|goal being scored]] for the opposition. Defenders often "turn behind" dangerous balls into the penalty area, particularly crosses, by kicking or heading the ball out of play behind their goal-line. In this way, the defender's aim is to concede a [[corner kick|corner]] rather than giving attacking players scoring opportunities. Consequently, the defender may misjudge and inadvertently turn the ball into his own goal, particularly if he is under pressure from attacking players who might otherwise score. The defending player who scored the own goal is personally "credited" with the goal as part of the statistical abstract of the game. The credit is annotated "(og)" to indicate its nature.
The [[Laws of the Game (association football)|Laws of the Game]] stipulate that an own goal cannot be scored directly from most methods of restarting the game; instead, a [[corner kick]] is awarded to the attacking team. This is the case for the [[Kick-off (association football)|kick-off]],<ref>LOTG 8.1</ref> [[goal kick]],{{#tag:ref|A corner is awarded provided the ball left the penalty area before entering the goal; otherwise the goal kick is retaken.<ref>LOTG 16</ref>|group="nb"}}<ref group="nb" name="explicitly2016"/> [[dropped-ball]] (since 2012)<ref>LOTG 8.2; [https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/affederation/administration/01/64/44/22/circularno.1302-amendmentstothelawsofthegame-2012_2013.pdf#page=3 FIFA Circular 1302 p.3]</ref>, [[throw-in]],<ref>LOTG 15</ref> corner kick,{{#tag:ref|This was explicitly added to the Laws of the Game in 2016,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2016/4/14/11429756/the-rules-of-soccer-are-changing-you-cant-score-an-own-goal-from-a?_ga=2.164167996.284906813.1502803412-329242256.1441989457|title=The rules of soccer are changing! You can't score an own goal from a corner anymore.|last=Thomas|first=Andi|date=14 Apr 2016|work=[[SBNation]]|accessdate=15 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="lotg2016changes">{{cite web|url=http://www.theifab.com/files/4%20-%20Presentation%20Law%20Changes_v0.3.pdf|title=Revision of The Laws of the Game: Summary of the Law changes for 2016/17 effective from 1 June 2016|author=IFAB |format=PDF|date=April 2016|pages=53, 55|accessdate=16 August 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160418081951/http://www.theifab.com/files/4%20-%20Presentation%20Law%20Changes_v0.3.pdf|archivedate=18 April 2016}}</ref> having previously been an official IFAB interpretation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hvsra.org/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/2016-2017-Law-changes-for-USSF-referees.pdf#page=42|title=2016–2017 Law Changes for USSF Referees|date=June 2016|publisher=HVSRA|pages=42, 42|accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref>|group="nb"|name="explicitly2016"}}<ref>LOTG 17</ref> and free kick ([[indirect free kick|indirect]] and [[direct free kick|direct]]).<ref>LOTG 13.1</ref>
The Laws do not stipulate any rules or procedures for crediting goals to players, and indeed such records are not a compulsory part of the game.<ref name="Cooper1997">{{cite journal |url=https://www.fifa.com/news/y=1997/m=4/news=when-own-goals-don-really-count-71928.html|title=When Own Goals Don't Really Count|last=Cooper|first=Keith|others=illustrated by Olé Andersen|date=17 April 1997|journal=FIFA Magazine|accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref> In 1997 FIFA issued detailed guidelines for crediting own goals, recognising the increasing commercial importance of statistics such as [[:Category:Lists of association football top scorers|top scorer awards]] and [[Fantasy football (association)|fantasy football]].<ref name="Cooper1997" /> The guidelines state that credit for scoring is decided by the referee, or match commissioner if present; and "[a] defender's intervention must be deliberate in order for an own goal to be registered against him".<ref name="Cooper1997" /> Regarding a shot which deflects or ricochets into the goal off a defender, some sources credit the score to the attacker; others count them as own goals; for others it depends on whether the original shot was off target; others are more nuanced.<ref name="Cooper1997" /> There was controversy in 2013 when the [[FA Premier League]] credited [[Tim Howard]] with an own goal when a shot came off the post, hit him in the back, and went in.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.si.com/soccer/planet-futbol/2013/10/05/tim-howard-own-goal-manchester-city |title=Did Tim Howard deserve an own goal against Manchester City? |first=Alexander |last=Abnos |date=5 October 2013 |work=SI.com }}</ref>
Major competitions may have video reviews which can alter the accreditation, such as the [[Dubious Goals Committee]] of the FA Premier League. In the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]], one of [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]]'s eight goals in winning the [[World Cup Golden Boot|Golden Boot]] was initially credited as an own goal but reassigned on appeal by Brazil.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-soccer-latam-ronaldo-profile-idUKTRE71D45U20110214|title=Eye for goal made Ronaldo a striker to be feared|last=Homewood|first=Brian|editor-first=Justin |editor-last=Palmer|date=14 February 2011|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> UEFA's review procedure was formalised in 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/520409/uefa-to-clarify-rules-on-deflected-own-goals |date=27 March 2008 |author=Reuters |work=ESPN |title=UEFA to clarify rules on deflected own goals }}</ref> {{As of|2006}}, the [[English Football League]] allowed the club which scored to nominate the scorer, which ''[[The Guardian]]'' criticised with an example from 2002: "every single national newspaper, agency and football factbook agreed that [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] defender [[Calum Davenport]] had scored an own goal against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]]. The Clarets, however, gave the goal to [[Gareth Taylor]]".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/aug/23/theknowledge.sport|title=The Knowledge: Is there really a Dubious Goals Committee?|last1=Ingle|first1=Sean|last2=Glendenning |first2=Barry |last3=Dart|first3=James |date=23 August 2006|work=[[TheGuardian.com]]|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref>
The most infamous own goal was by [[Andrés Escobar]] of [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]] in the [[1994 FIFA World Cup]] which lost [[United States v Colombia (1994 FIFA World Cup)|the match]] against the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] and knocked Colombia out; a week later, Escobar was shot dead in Colombia by a drug gang member whose boss had lost betting on the match.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://asktheref.com/Soccer%20Rules/Question/21754/|title=Question 21754: Law 10 - Method of Scoring|date=7 August 2009|accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref>
==Ice hockey== If a [[goal (hockey)|goal]] is scored by a player on the defending team, credit for the goal goes to the last player on the other team to have touched the [[hockey puck|puck]]; this is because own goals in hockey are typically cases where the player so credited had the shot deflected, but this convention is used even where this is not the case. Occasionally, it is also credited to the closest player to the goal from the other team if he is determined to have caused the opposing player to shoot it into the wrong net. Assists are not awarded on an own goal because the defending team has possession of the puck between any pass and the goal itself. Occasionally in the [[National Hockey League|NHL]], players have directed the puck into their own [[empty net]], either late in the game or because of a [[delayed penalty call]]. This was the situation which resulted in [[Billy Smith (ice hockey)|Billy Smith]] of the [[New York Islanders]] becoming the first [[goaltender]] to receive credit for a goal in the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]. In some parts of [[Canada]], an own goal is referred to as a [[Glossary of ice hockey terms|limoges]]. The term is believed to have originated in [[New Brunswick]] (approximately 1970) and became more common in the greater [[Toronto]] region starting in the 1990s{{Citation needed|date=May 2016}}.
==Field hockey== Treatment of "own goals" in field hockey has varied over recent years. In 2013 the [[International Hockey Federation]] (FIH) implemented a "mandatory experiment" such that a deflection of a shot from outside the shooting circle from a defender would be equivalent to a touch from an attacker, and thus if the shot continued into the goal the score would be counted. This proved unpopular and the change was reversed.<ref name="FIH-withdraw">{{cite news|last1=Bone|first1=Ross|title=Talking Hockey: own goal rule wiped out creativity, though umpires likely to disagree|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/hockey/10477968/Talking-Hockey-own-goal-rule-wiped-out-creativity-though-umpires-likely-to-disagree.html|accessdate=15 August 2016|work=Telegraph|date=27 November 2013}}</ref>
Presently rule 8.1 states that ''"A goal is scored when the ball is played within the circle by an attacker and does not travel outside the circle before passing completely over the goal-line and under the crossbar."'' Added clarification: ''"The ball may be played by a defender or touch their body before or after being played in the circle by an attacker."''<ref name="FIH_rules">{{cite web|title=Rules of Hockey|url=http://www.fih.ch/media/8997802/rules-of-hockey-2015.pdf|publisher=FIH|accessdate=15 August 2016|date=2015}}</ref> Thus, an "own goal" may occur, but in such situations the goal will likely be credited to the attacker whose initial play into the circle was necessary for the goal to stand.
==Basketball== When accidentally scoring at an opposing team's basket (basketball's equivalent of an "own goal"), the goal is credited to an offensive player. One typical own-goal scenario occurs when a player tries to block a goal shot but ends up knocking the ball into the goal.
In [[National Federation of State High School Associations|NFHS]] basketball, the two points are merely listed for the scoring team, as a footnote.
In [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] basketball, the rules state: "When a player scores a field goal in the opponent’s basket, it shall count two points for the opponent regardless of the location on the playing court from where it was released. Such a field goal shall not be credited to a player in the scorebook but shall be indicated with a footnote."
In [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] rules, the goal is credited to the player on the scoring team who is closest to defensive shooter and is mentioned in a footnote.
Under [[FIBA]] rules, the player designated captain is credited with the basket.
==American football== When a ball carrier is tackled or exits the field of play within the end zone being defended by his team, the result is a [[Safety (American football score)|safety]] and the opposing team is awarded two points, and receives the ball after a free kick taken at the twenty-yard line. (This does not apply if the ball carrier secures possession of the ball in the end zone as a result of an interception or a kick; in that case, no points are awarded and the play is considered a [[touchback]].) In Canadian football, if a scrimmage kick (punt or missed field goal attempt) is kicked into the end zone and the opponent does not advance it out, the kicking team is awarded a [[Single (Canadian football)|single]], worth one point.
A true "own goal", in which the team place kicks or drop kicks the ball through their own goal posts (which has never happened at any level in football history and would require either a very strong headwind or a deliberate act of sabotage), is treated as any other backward kick in most leagues' rule books. Backward kicks are treated as [[fumble]]s, and as such, a backward kick through the back of the end zone, including through the goal posts, is scored as a safety. This occurred in a 2012 game between two Texas high schools; a punter kicked against a strong wind that blew the ball backward into the end zone, where the defense took control of it.<ref>Smith, Cameron (16 Oct. 2012) "[https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/highschool-prep-rally/texas-wind-knocks-punt-back-incredibly-unlikely-safety-151900255.html Texas wind knocks punt back for incredibly unlikely safety]"</ref>
In the final minutes of a game, a team may take a deliberate safety in order to get the free kick, rather than punting from the end zone. In 2003, the [[New England Patriots]] came back to win a game after giving a safety that put them three points behind.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?id=1653659 |title=Belichick's gamble pays off for Patriots - NFL - ESPN |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=2003-11-04 |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref> Similarly, the [[Baltimore Ravens]] took a safety with twelve seconds left in [[Super Bowl XLVII]] instead of punting out of the end zone, cutting their lead to three points but winning the game since they were able to burn eight seconds off the clock with the safety play, and the opposing [[San Francisco 49ers]] were unable to score on the ensuing free kick.
==Canadian football==
In the [[2017 Grey Cup]], the [[Calgary Stampeders]] deliberately took a safety when their punter [[Rob Maver]], having lost control of a high snap, was faced with loss of down deep in his own territory. He intentionally kicked the ball backwards through the back of his own end zone for a safety.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ottawacitizen.com/sports/football/argonauts-slay-mighty-stampeders-in-snowy-epic-grey-cup/wcm/cbf1448f-638d-49d3-aa91-17a64e848367|title=Argonauts slay mighty Stampeders in epic, snowy Grey Cup|last=Baines|first=Tim|date=26 November 2017|publisher=[[Ottawa Citizen]]|accessdate=26 November 2017}}</ref>
==Gaelic football== [[Gaelic football]]ers can play the ball with their hands; therefore, they have a much greater degree of control over the ball and thus, own goals are much rarer than they are in association football. They do occur, and two were scored by [[Mayo GAA|Mayo]] in the [[2016 All-Ireland Senior Football Championship Final#Match 1|drawn 2016 All-Ireland SFC Final]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2016/0918/817360-all-ireland-final-updates-dublin-v-mayo/|title=Recap: How the All-Ireland football final unfolded|date=18 September 2016|work=[[RTÉ.ie]]|accessdate=15 August 2017}}</ref>
As an own goal is scored when the ball goes under the crossbar, so an "own point" is scored (like any other point) when the ball goes over the crossbar. However, when a shot on goal is deflected over the bar by the defending team, the point is credited to the attacker who shot and not considered an "own point".
==Australian rules football== {{main|Rushed behind}} As a legitimate defensive play, an Australian rules football defender may concede an "own score". Such a score, referred to as a ''rushed behind'' and statistically credited to no player (score sheets simply include the tally of rushed behinds), results in the opposition team scoring one point. A defending player may choose to concede a rushed behind when the risk of the opposition scoring a goal (worth six points) is high. It is impossible for a team to concede an own goal worth six points.

The club's home arena was [[Universal Sports Palace Molot|Molot Sports Hall]]. The team played in the [[Russian Basketball Super League|Russian Super League]]. ==History== The club was established in the year 1995 on the basis of the local Technical University team. Ural Great won the [[Russian Basketball Super League|Russian League]] championship on two occasions, in the years 2001 and 2002 and the [[Russian Basketball Cup|Russian Cup]] in the year 2004. They also won the [[North European Basketball League|NEBL]] championship in the year 2001. Ural also won the [[EuroCup Challenge]] championship in the year 2006. On October 14, 2008, court bailiffs seized Ural Great's office furniture and equipment for unpaid debts.[http://www.gazeta.ru/news/sport/2008/10/14/n_1282804.shtml Baliffs seize Ural-Great property Founded in 1975, SHF is affiliated to the [[International Handball Federation]] and [[Asian Handball Federation]]. SHF is also affiliated to the [[Saudi Arabian Olympic Committee]], [[West Asian Handball Federation]] and the [[Arab Handball Federation]]. It is based in [[Riyadh]].{{cite web|url=http://ihf.info/TheIHF/ContinentalFederations/AsianHandballFederation(AHF)/ListofFederations/SaudiHandballFederation.aspx|title=Profile at IHF website|date=27 October 2017|work=ihf.info}} ==Competitions== * [[Prince Faisal bin Fahad Saudi Handball League]] ==National teams== * [[Saudi Arabia national handball team]] * [[Saudi Arabia national junior handball team]] * [[Saudi Arabia national youth handball team]] * [[Saudi Arabia women's national handball team]] * [[Saudi Arabia women's junior national handball team]] * [[Saudi Arabia women's youth national handball team]] ==Competitions hosted== * [[2012 Asian Men's Handball Championship]] * [[2008 Asian Men's Club League Handball Championship]] * [[2011 Asian Men's Club League Handball Championship]] ==International medals== {| border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" |- bgcolor="#efefef" align="center" ! {{more citations needed|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox sport governing body |name = Sikkim Cricket Association |abbrev = SCA |logo = |sport = [[Cricket]] |category = |image = |caption = Logo of Sikkim Cricket Association |jurisdiction = [[Sikkim]] |founded = {{Start date|1987}} |aff = [[Board of Control for Cricket in India]] |affdate = |regionyear = |headquarters = Hotel Soman Delek |location = [[Gangtok]] |president = Mr. Lobzang G. Tenzing |chairman = |chairperson = |chair = |chiefexec = |secretary =Mr. Sonam Palden Bhutia |key staff = |url = http://www.sikkimcricket.com/ |countryflag =India }}
'''Sikkim Cricket Association''' or SCA is the governing body of the [[Cricket]] in Indian state sikkim and [[Sikkim cricket team]]. It is headquartered in Gangtok, the capital of Sikkim. Among other duties, SCA is responsible for organizing various cricketing tournaments in the state. It is affiliated to the [[Board of Control for Cricket in India]] as an Full Member.
[[Mining Ground| Mining Cricket Ground]] in [[Rangpo]], [[East Sikkim]] is the official cricket ground in Sikkim and has been leased to Sikkim Cricket Association in 2002 for 20 years by the Government of Sikkim.
Mr. Lobzang G. Tenzing is the current President of Sikkim Cricket Association.<ref name="SSL">{{cite web|url=https://www.sportstarlive.com/cricket/northeast-states-woes-first-class-cricket-ranji-trophy/article24471707.ece |title=Ground reality hits Northeast states before first-class debut |work=Sport Star Live |accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref>
== History == '''Sikkim Cricket Association''' was formed and registered under Government of Sikkim in 1987. In 1989 [[Polly Umrigar]]<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2018-02-14|title=Polly Umrigar|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Polly_Umrigar&oldid=825621263|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> and [[Madhav Mantri]]<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2018-01-06|title=Madhav Mantri|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Madhav_Mantri&oldid=818963724|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> both BCCI members visited Sikkim and were very impressed with the [[Mining Ground|Mining Cricket Ground]]<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-09-10|title=Mining Ground|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mining_Ground&oldid=799815582|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> (the home ground of SCA) and its potential of being converted into a world class stadium.
It was in 1991, Sikkim Cricket Association got affiliated to [[Board of Control for Cricket in India|Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI)]].<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2018-03-04|title=Board of Control for Cricket in India|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Board_of_Control_for_Cricket_in_India&oldid=828755069|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref>
In 1994, Sikkim team participated in their first Junior Level National Tournament and also in 1997 the first match was played in Mining Cricket Ground, Rangpo, Sikkim against Bihar U-19 team and the match was Inaugurated by The Honorable Chief Minister of Sikkim.
== Tournaments == The '''Sikkim Cricket Association''' participates in following BCCI tournaments.
* [[Ranji Trophy]](Multi Day) * [[Vijay Hazare Trophy]](One Day) * [[Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy]] (Twenty20) * Col. C. K. Nayudu Trophy (Multi Day) U23 Men's * Men's U23 One Day * Vinoo Mankad Trophy (One Day) U19 Men's * Cooch Behar Trophy (Multi Day) U19 Men's * Vijay Merchant Trophy (Multi Day) U16 Men's * [[Senior Women's One Day League]] * [[Senior Women's T20 League]] * Women's U23 One Day League * Women's U23 Twenty20 League * Women's U19 One Day League * Women's U19 Twenty20 League
== Home Ground == * [[Mining Ground|Mining Cricket Ground]]

revision.comment: Fallacy is the wrong word. No logical or rhetorical fallacy is employed in the claim that spot reduction is real, even if the claim is false.
revision.text:
'''Spot reduction''' refers to the claim that [[adipose tissue|fat]] can be targeted for reduction from a specific area of the body through [[physical exercise|exercise]] of specific [[muscle]]s in the desired area, such as exercising the [[Human abdomen#Muscles a of the abdominal wall|abdominal muscles]] in an effort to lose weight in or around one's midsection. Advertisers exploit this concept when advertising exercise-related products.<ref name="exrx">{{cite web |url=http://www.exrx.net/WeightTraining/Myths.html |title=Fat loss and weight training myths|accessdate=2008-06-10 |publisher=ExRx.net }}{{MEDRS|date=October 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Weighted Crunch (behind-head).gif|thumb|A common belief is that doing [[crunch (exercise)|crunch]]es alone reduces [[belly fat]].]] The scientific consensus among fitness experts and researchers is that spot reduction is a myth. Studies largely show that it is not possible to reduce fat in one area by exercising that body part alone.<ref>{{cite web |first1=Elena |last1=Perry |title=Targeted Fat Loss: Myth or Reality? |url=http://www.yalescientific.org/2011/04/targeted-fat-loss-myth-or-reality/ |work=Yale Scientific |year=2001 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first1=Carolyn |last1=Nickol |url=http://www.netwellness.uc.edu/question.cfm/21417.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101111012535/http://www.netwellness.uc.edu/question.cfm/21417.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2010-11-11 |title=Spot Fat Reduction |publisher=University Fitness Center, University of Cincinnati |year=2001 }}</ref><ref name="wilmore">{{cite book |first1=Jack H. |last1=Wilmore |first2=David L. |last2=Costill |year=1999 |title=Physiology of Sport and Exercise |publisher=Human Kinetics |isbn=978-0-7360-0084-0 }}{{pn|date=October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ramírez-Campillo |first1=Rodrigo |last2=Andrade |first2=David C. |last3=Campos-Jara |first3=Christian |last4=Henríquez-Olguín |first4=Carlos |last5=Alvarez-Lepín |first5=Cristian |last6=Izquierdo |first6=Mikel |title=Regional Fat Changes Induced by Localized Muscle Endurance Resistance Training |journal=Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research |volume=27 |issue=8 |pages=2219–24 |year=2013 |pmid=23222084 |doi=10.1519/JSC.0b013e31827e8681 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vispute |first1=Sachin S |last2=Smith |first2=John D |last3=LeCheminant |first3=James D |last4=Hurley |first4=Kimberly S |title=The Effect of Abdominal Exercise on Abdominal Fat |journal=Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research |volume=25 |issue=9 |pages=2559–64 |year=2011 |pmid=21804427 |doi=10.1519/JSC.0b013e3181fb4a46 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Katch |first1=Frank I. |last2=Clarkson |first2=Priscilla M. |last3=Kroll |first3=Walter |last4=McBride |first4=Thomas |last5=Wilcox |first5=Anthony |title=Effects of Sit up Exercise Training on Adipose Cell Size and Adiposity |journal=Research Quarterly for Exercise and Sport |volume=55 |issue=3 |year=1984 |pages=242–7 |doi=10.1080/02701367.1984.10609359 }}</ref> Instead, fat is lost from the entire body as a result of [[Diet (nutrition)|diet]] and regular exercise.<ref name="wilmore" /> Muscle growth in the abdominal region does not reduce fat in that region.<ref name="Harshbarger">Dave Harshbarger. [http://www.hsc.wvu.edu/Wellness/Ask-The-Expert/Default.aspx Wellness Program]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101005080913/http://www.hsc.wvu.edu/Wellness/Ask-The-Expert/Default.aspx |date=2010-10-05 }} West Virginia University.</ref> Instead, being on a caloric deficit is recommended for reducing abdominal fat.{{not in citation given|date=May 2018}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.webmd.com/diet/features/the-truth-about-belly-fat |title=How to Lose Belly Fat: Tips for a Flatter Stomach |publisher=Webmd.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-25}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Toning exercises]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox stadium |stadium_name = Springfield Park |nickname = |logo_image = |image = |caption = |capacity = 40 000 (maximum) |former_names = |location = [[Wigan]] |coordinates = |built by = Winnard and Weston |opened = 1897 |closed = 1999 |demolished = 1999 |architect = Richardson Thomas Johnson |construction_cost = [[Pound sterling|£]]16 000 |owners = The Wigan Trotting and Athletic Grounds Company Ltd. 1896-1899
The Royal London Friendly Society. 1899-
Wigan Athletic 1932-1999 |operator = |seating_capacity = |surface = Grass |dimensions = |tenants = [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] (1932-1999)
[[Wigan County F.C.|Wigan County]] (1897-1900)
[[Wigan United A.F.C.|Wigan United]] (1901-1903)
[[Wigan Town A.F.C|Wigan Town]] (1905-1908)
[[Wigan Borough F.C.|Wigan Borough]] (1919-1932)
[[Wigan Warriors]] (1901-1902)
[[Blackpool Borough|Springfield Borough]] (1987–1988) }} '''Springfield Park''' was a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Wigan]], [[Greater Manchester]]. It was the home ground of [[Wigan Athletic F.C.]] until the club moved to the new [[JJB Stadium]] (now DW Stadium) after the 1998–99 season. At its largest, the stadium held 40,000. In its 102-year existence the ground only saw 32 years as a Football League venue, 11 years for [[Wigan Borough F.C.]] and 21 years for Wigan Athletic FC, before it was demolished to make way for a housing estate in 1999. The stadium had previously been home to [[Wigan County F.C.|Wigan County]], [[Wigan United A.F.C.|Wigan United]], [[Wigan Town A.F.C|Wigan Town]], and [[Wigan Borough]] (previously Wigan United and Wigan Association) as well as [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] and [[Blackpool Borough|Springfield Borough]] rugby league sides. It was also used for [[Harness racing|horse trotting]], as a track cycling [[velodrome]], for wrestling and for athletics. Springfield Park was designed by architect Richardson Thomas Johnson and built in 1897 at a cost of £16,000. It was owned by The Wigan Trotting and Athletic Grounds Company Ltd. The first professional football match at the stadium took place in September 1897 when Wigan County played Burton Swifts in a friendly match.Wigan Athletic AFC - An A–Z, [[Dean Hayes]]. {{ISBN|1-874181-16-0}} ==Association Football== ===History=== Wigan County were the first team to play at Springfield Park. Their greatest event was a 1–0 loss at the hands of [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] before their liquidation and extinction three years after their 1897 formation. [[Wigan United A.F.C.|Wigan United]] took the lease at Springfield Park in 1901, competing for two seasons in the Lancashire League. After being drawn away to [[Stalybridge Rovers F.C.|Stalybridge Rovers]] in the third round of the Rawcliffe Cup, they declined to play due to a waterlogged pitch. However, the referee ruled otherwise, leaving Stalybridge to kick off, dribble and place the ball into the net.Wigan Athletic AFC - An A–Z, [[Dean Hayes]]. {{ISBN|1-874181-16-0}}[[Wigan Town A.F.C.|Wigan Town]] would be the third attempt to establish football in Wigan in 1905, but it too would fail to survive for more than three years. After a period of inactivity at Springfield Park due to the First World War, [[Wigan United A.F.C.|Wigan United]] beat Fleetwood 2–0 on 6 September 1919 in the West Lancs League. This was the first official game after the war and would lead to the club taking the lease for the ground on 2 December 1919 for the rest of the season. United eventually became [[Wigan Borough F.C.]] in 1920 and became one of the founder members of the [[Football League Third Division North]]. They won their first game, against Nelson, 2–1 in front of 9,000 spectators. The club's best performance was in 1928–29 when they reached the Third round of the [[FA Cup]]. This was to be the largest attendance ever recorded at Springfield Park, with 30,443 spectators watching a 3–1 loss to [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]]. Wigan Borough resigned from the football league during the [[1931-32 in English football|1931–32]] season. Shortly after Borough went out of business, a new club, [[Wigan Athletic F.C.]], was formed and continued to play their home games at Springfield Park. After lengthy negotiations, Wigan Athletic purchased the ground from the owner of [[Woodhouse Lane Stadium]] for £2,800 with the proviso that greyhound racing never take place at Springfield Park.Wigan Athletic AFC - An A–Z, [[Dean Hayes]]. {{ISBN|1-874181-16-0}} During the 1952–53 season, the main stand was razed to the ground by fire, resulting in major fundraising efforts for the construction of a new stand. The following season, a record crowd of 27,526 watched Wigan Athletic beat [[Hereford United]] 4–1. To this day, it is the largest attendance ever recorded between two non-league clubs excluding Wembley finals.[http://www.wafc.co.uk/honours/index.htm WAFC.co.uk - club honours] 19 October 1966 marked the first floodlit match at Springfield Park, when Wigan Athletic played Crewe Alexandra. This was a full year before floodlights were installed at [[Central Park (Wigan)|Central Park]]. In October 1978, [[Zambia national football team|Zambia]] –coached by [[Brian Tiler]], himself an ex-Latics manager– became the first national team to play at Springfield Park. Wigan won the game 2–1. [[Wigan Athletic F.C.]] moved to the new [[JJB Stadium]] after the 1999 season. The final competitive goal to be scored at the stadium was by Manchester City's [[Paul Dickov]]. ===Attendances=== ====Wigan Borough==== =====Football League===== # [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]], 1 April 1929. Division 3 North: 15,162 # [[Accrington Stanley F.C. (1891)|Accrington Stanley]], 14 October 1922. Division 3 North: 13,000 # [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]], 27 August 1923. Division 3 North: 13,000 # [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]], 1 September 1928. Division 3 North: 12,646 =====Other===== # [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]], 12 January 1929. FA Cup Round 3: 39,433 ====Wigan Athletic==== =====Football League===== # [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]], 26 December 1983. Division 3: 10,045 # [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]], 19 April 1986. Division 3: 9,485 # [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]], 3 March 1979. Division 4: 9,427 =====Other===== # [[Hereford United F.C.|Hereford United]], 1953–54. FA Cup Round 2: 27,526 (record attendance for a match between two non-league teams at a non-league ground) # [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], 1953–54. FA Cup Round 3: 26,500 # [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], 1934–35. FA Cup Round 3: 25,304 ====Neutral Venue==== # [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] -v- [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], 2 October 1922. Whitehaven Pit Disaster Fund: 15,000 ==Rugby League== [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan Rugby League]] team became sub-tenants of Springfield Park (which they shared with Wigan United who had playing preference) playing their first game there on 14 September 1901. A crowd of 4,123 saw them beat Morecambe 12–0. Wigan rugby league team's record crowd at Springfield was 10,111 when they beat Widnes on 19 March 1902. The last game was on 28 April 1902 when Wigan beat the Rest of Lancashire Senior Competition. Wigan then moved to [[Central Park (Wigan)|Central Park]]. The only other rugby league team to play at the ground was [[Blackpool Borough|Springfield Borough]] who played at Springfield Park for one season in 1987–88. A continuation of Springfield Borough still play under the guise of [[Blackpool Panthers]] in [[League 1 (rugby league)|League 1]]. {{coord|53|33|17.69|N|2|39|02.38|W|type:landmark|display=title}} ==Cycling== The concrete cycle track featured a home straight 29 ft (approx 9m) wide, while the banking was 24 ft wide, rising 7 ft. It was used regularly for competitions; local racing cyclists who raced there included [[Benjamin Jones (cyclist)|Benjamin Jones]], who competed in the [[1908 Summer Olympics|1908 London Olympic Games]] winning two gold medals.{{cite web|title=1896–1919 The Early Years|url=http://springfieldparkmemorial.weebly.com/1896-1919-the-early-years.html|work=The Springfield Park Memorial|accessdate=3 July 2012}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{fchd|id=WIGANB|name=Wigan Borough}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081024231256/http://www.chilvers1.demon.co.uk/Springfield.htm Ultimate Wigan Athletic Website] * [http://springfieldparkmemorial.weebly.com The Springfield Park Memorial] * [http://www.wiganborough.bernardramsdale.com/index.html Wigan Borough Football Club - Complete] * [http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk Wigan Athletic official website] * [http://wigantown.weebly.com/index.html Wigan Town A.F.C.] {{Wigan Athletic F.C.}} {{Wigan Borough F.C.}} {{Wigan Warriors}} [[Category:Defunct football venues in England]] [[Category:Defunct rugby league venues in England]] [[Category:Defunct velodromes in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Defunct sports venues in Greater Manchester]] [[Category:1897 establishments in England]] [[Category:1999 disestablishments in England]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1897]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 1999]] [[Category:Demolished buildings and structures in Greater Manchester]] [[Category:Sport in Wigan]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Wigan]]

revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox Stadium | name = St Julian's Road | nickname = | image = | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[Omagh]], [[Northern Ireland]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1990 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | construction_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | tenants = formerly [[Omagh Town F.C.|Omagh Town]] }} '''St Julian's Road''' is a former [[Association football|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Omagh]], [[Northern Ireland]]. It was the home ground of [[Omagh Town F.C.|Omagh Town]] until the dissolution of the club in June 2005. The ground, which featured a grass pitch, had a capacity of 5000, made up of thirty 30 VIP places, 250 covered seats, 4720 standing places (3220 covered and 1500 uncovered).<ref name="world">[http://www.worldstadia.com/stadium/northern%20ireland/st_julians_road/1278.php?PHPSESSID=f78b5e30907e937c1367d27c973179d6 Details for St Julians Road, Omagh]</ref>
==History== Town first leased the Mullaghmore site, which had previously served as a rubbish tip, from [[Omagh District Council]] in 1987, with the stadium opening three years later.<ref name="world"/> As well as football the ground has also hosted [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] events.<ref>[http://gaaboard.com/board/index.php?topic=7799.55;wap2 Still no place for gaelic games in NI state school sector]</ref>
==Charity matches== Among the clubs to play at St. Julian's Road were [[Manchester United]], who faced Omagh Town in a friendly game there in 1999 in order to raise money for the [[Omagh bombing]] appeal.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4161/is_19990613/ai_n14488442/ Manchester United set for match at Omagh]</ref> The match ended in a 9-0 win to the visitors with [[Teddy Sheringham]] netting four times.<ref>[http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/manu/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/99/08/03/SOCCER_Man_Utd.html&TEAMHD=manu&DIV=prem&TEAM=MANCHESTER--UNITED&RH=Manchester--United&PREV_SEASON=1998&BID= Omagh Town 0 Manchester United 9]</ref> Both [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] also faced the home side at St Julian's Road as part of the same charity initiative.<ref>[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/FOOTBALL%3A+HOULLIER+CHOOSES+FROM+A+FULL-STRENGTH+POOL%3B+Omagh+Town+v...-a060332757 FOOTBALL: HOULLIER CHOOSES FROM A FULL-STRENGTH POOL; Omagh Town v Liverpool]</ref>
==Current use== Following the collapse of the football club, the stadium fell into disuse although in January 2010, Sean Begley, a [[Sinn Féin]] councillor, brought a proposal before the Council to revive St Julian's Road as a football venue.<ref>[http://www.westtyronesinnfein.com/news/15621 Proposal to redevelop St Julian's Road ground to go before council]</ref>
==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IHu0823kPC8 The Ulster Groundhop of St Julian's Road] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100906132914/http://home.online.no/~smogols/ifcp/clubs/defunctomaghtown/clubomaghtown.htm Photo of the main stand]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Great Match (The Flying Dutchman and Voltigeur).jpg|thumb|right|240px|The Great Match by J F Herring: "Volti" is beaten by "The Flyer"]]
'''The Great Match''' is the name given to a [[match race]] between two of the most famous British [[thoroughbred]] [[racehorse]]s of the 19th Century - [[Voltigeur (horse)|Voltigeur]] and [[The Flying Dutchman (horse)|The Flying Dutchman]]. The race took place at [[York Racecourse|York]] on 31 May 1851 for a purse of 1,000 sovereigns.
==Background==
The Flying Dutchman was a five-year-old, who had won the 1849 [[Epsom Derby]] and [[St. Leger Stakes|St Leger]] and, as a four-year-old, the 1850 [[Ascot Gold Cup]]. So dominant had he been that the whip had only been raised on him once, during his Derby victory.
Voltigeur was a year younger, and in 1850 had followed in The Flying Dutchman's hoof prints by taking both [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] and [[St. Leger Stakes|St Leger]] (in a rematch after an initial [[Tie (draw)|dead heat]]). In winning the Derby, he had posted a time ten seconds faster than that of The Flying Dutchman the year previously.<ref name=TBH>{{cite web|url=http://www.tbheritage.com/Portraits/Voltigeur.html| last=Martiniak| first=Elizabeth| title=Voltigeur |publisher=Thoroughbred Heritage |accessdate=11 April 2013}}</ref>
Two days after Voltigeur's St Leger victory, the two horses met for the first time in the [[Doncaster Cup]]. The younger horse was in receipt of 19 pounds from his rival<ref name=NHM>{{cite web|url=http://blog.nhrm.co.uk/index.php/match-races/ |title=Match Races |publisher=National Horseracing Museum |accessdate=11 April 2013}}</ref> and as a result, the previously unbeaten Flying Dutchman went down to a half length defeat, although in some ways the victory was deemed unsatisfactory. Rumours abounded that the Flying Dutchman's [[jockey]], [[Charles Marlow (jockey)|Charles Marlow]], was the worse for drink<ref>{{cite web|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NENZC18510301.2.8&srpos=3&e=01-01-1848-31-12-1851--10--1----2the+flying+dutchman-- |title=DONCASTER RACES |publisher=Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle |date=1 March 1851 |accessdate=2012-01-03}}</ref> and consequently ignored instructions to wait on the colt, declaring "I'll show you what I've got under me today!" and setting a ridiculously fast pace.<ref name="Mortimer">{{cite book | last1 = Mortimer | first1 = Roger |last2=Onslow|first2=Richard|last3=Willett|first3=Peter| title = Biographical Encyclopedia of British Flat Racing| publisher=Macdonald and Jane’s | year = 1978| isbn = 0-354-08536-0}}</ref>
It was subsequently agreed that the two would meet again the following spring for a purse of 2,000 guineas, with each owner putting up half the stake.<ref name="autogenerated3">{{cite web|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=DSC18740627.2.23&srpos=32&e=01-01-1874-31-12-1874--10--31----0Voltigeur-- |title=ANSWERS TO CORRESPONDENTS |publisher=Daily Southern Cross |date=27 June 1874 |accessdate=2012-01-04}}</ref>
==Race==
The famous handicapper [[Henry John Rous]] set the weights for the second match, giving The Flying Dutchman a weight of 120½ pounds to Voltigeur's 112.
The race between the two Yorkshire horses proved extremely popular, drawing a crowd of between 100,000 <ref name="autogenerated3" /> and 150,000, an all-time record for York.<ref name=facts>{{cite web| url=http://www.yorkracecourse.co.uk/about-york-racecourse/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-us| title=10 things you didn't know about us| publisher=York Racecourse| accessdate=11 April 2013| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728230324/http://yorkracecourse.co.uk/about-york-racecourse/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-us| archivedate=28 July 2013| df=}}</ref> Some even walked from as far afield as [[Richmond, North Yorkshire]] to be there.<ref name=TBH />
Even the horses' exercise gallops attracted large crowds of fans attempting to assess their relative condition.
Unlike their previous meeting, The Flying Dutchman was successfully restrained in the early stages as Voltigeur, under [[Nat Flatman]], made the running. In the final furlong the Flying Dutchman moved up level with his rival and then pulled ahead to win by a length.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NENZC18511101.2.9&srpos=4&e=01-01-1848-31-12-1851--10--1----2the+flying+dutchman-- |title=Papers Past — Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle — 1 November 1851 — SPORTING |publisher=Paperspast.natlib.govt.nz |date= |accessdate=2012-01-03}}</ref>
==Aftermath==
The event was immortalised in paintings by [[Harry Hall (painter)|Harry Hall]], first exhibited in Buchanan Street, [[Glasgow]] later that year,<ref name=herald>{{cite news |title=The Flying Dutchman and Voltigeur |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=18510912&id=_khEAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yrEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4667,6364963|format= |work=[[Glasgow Herald]] |location=[[Glasgow]] |date=12 September 1851 |accessdate=11 April 2013 }}</ref> and [[John F. Herring]], whose work became so famous there was scarcely a village in the [[British Empire]] without a copy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=GRA18740608.2.13&srpos=2&e=01-01-1874-31-12-1874--10--1----0Voltigeur-- |title=SPORTING NOTES |publisher=Grey River Argus |date= 8 June 1874|accessdate=2012-01-04}}</ref>
As for the horses, The Flying Dutchman was retired to [[Stud farm|stud]] after the race. Voltigeur, on the other hand, carried on racing. The very day after the match race, he went down to defeat in the Ainsty Hunt Cup, conceding 37 pounds to a classy filly named Nancy.<ref name=TBH />
The next season, when he was five, he won the race named in honour of his old rival, The Flying Dutchman Handicap, run at York, before finishing unplaced in his final three racecourse appearances, including the Ascot Gold Cup, and then retiring to stud himself.<ref name=TBH />
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:British racehorses]] [[Category:Horse races in Great Britain]] [[Category:Racing]]
